awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Developing A Complete Membrane-Cytoskeleton Model for Human Erythrocyte
awd_abstract_narration:
1067523/1066469
Zhang/Li

During its 120-day life span, a human red blood cell (RBC) circulates a million times in human body and often squeezes through narrow capillaries, exhibiting an amazing ability of control over its shape and mechanical properties under external mechanical stimuli. This collaborative project aims to develop a complete human RBC model coupling the coarse-grained membrane model and cytoskeleton model and to study the molecular regulatory mechanisms in RBC deformation. The complete RBC model is molecularly based, and thus faithful to the underlying nano-scale architecture of the RBC. Upon validation against existing analytical and experimental studies, the complete RBC model will be employed to identify molecular origins of RBC deformation and disorders under combined metabolic activation and mechanical loading.

The intellectual merit of this project resides in the development of the first ever computational whole-cell platform for human erythrocyte. The coarse-grained modeling will establish a direct link between nanostructural changes and observables such as fluctuation, shape, and disorders. When integrated with existing microscopic models of key components in living cells, such as actin and focal adhesion complex, the computational whole-cell platform established herein will help foster transformative progress for the analysis of RBC responses in particular and cell mechanics in general.

The first-ever computational whole-cell platform built upon a detailed blueprint of all the nanostructural members of an entire RBC cell at nanometer resolution will have a revolutionary impact on computational cell biology. The computational platform facilitates identifying the molecular origins of RBC disorders, presenting another key impact of the proposed project. The educational program will enhance minority involvement and participation in science and engineering, and stimulate the interests of students in Penn State and MIT in the emerging field of multiscale modeling of cell mechanics.

por.por_cntn:
In this collaborative project, we have developed a complete human red blood cell (RBC) model, building upon the coarse-grained fluid membrane model and chain-of-beads spectrin cytoskeleton model previously developed by the two PIs. We then employed the complete RBC model to identify molecular origins of RBC deformation and disorders under mechanical loading and biochemical changes.  We have simulated the shear responses of both the healthy and plasmodium falciparum (Pf) infected RBC membranes, and rationalized the underlying molecular mechanisms of the loss of deformability of the infected RBC.

Plasmodium falciparum (Pf), the most virulent human malaria parasite, invades human RBC, exports proteins to modify RBC membranes, and endows RBC with high stiffness and cytoadherence, subsequently leading to blockage of blood vessels and dysfunction of organs. Despite considerable progress in understanding this complicated process, the molecular mechanism responsible for the dramatic loss of deformability in Pf-infected RBC had remained elusive. Using an ultrastructure-based coarse-grained (CG) RBC membrane model, we reveal that Plasmodium falciparum exploits fundamental materials design principles, including compositing, reinforcing, and strain hardening, to stiffen the membranes, wherein lipid knobs play a dual stiffening role. On one hand, lipid knobs act as structural strengtheners to the spectrin network; on the other hand, the presence of lipid knobs results in strain inhomogeneity in the spectrin network with elevated shear strain in the knob-free regions, which effectively stiffens the network given its elastic strain-hardening property. The shear moduli of Pf-infected RBC at different asexual stages predicted by the CG model are in good agreement with experimental results. 

We have developed a highly efficient composite membrane-cytoskeleton RBC membrane model, which enables a systematic study of the correlations between the structural changes on the shear elasticity of both healthy and infected RBC membranes. Our simulation results show that the presence of knobs is a major cause of the increased shear modulus of Pf-infected RBC membranes. The presence of knob domains not only strengthens spectrin network as structural reinforcements, but also significantly elevates the shear strain in the knob-free regions of the spectrin network. The knob-induced strain inhomogeneity combines with the strain hardening property of the spectrin network to orchestrate the stiffening of the Pf-infected RBC membranes. The predicted shear moduli of Pf-infected RBC membranes by the CG model fall in the range of the experimental measurements. In addition to providing a highly efficient RBC membrane model for the study of RBC disorders and a fundamental understanding on the stiffening mechanism of Pf-infected RBCs, our simulation results shed light on the pathogenesis of malaria.
